conclusion: Two wooden blocks A and B, each with mass m, are connected by a light spring with spring constant k.
Initially, the system is at rest, and block B is in contact with the ground.
A constant upward force F is applied to block A, causing the spring to stretch.
Block B leaves the ground when the upward force F is sufficient to overcome the gravitational force acting on B.
The spring force F_spring acting upward on B must equal the gravitational force F_gravity acting downward on B for block B to leave the ground.
The gravitational force on B is F_gravity = m g, where g is the acceleration due to gravity.
The spring force when B just leaves the ground is F_spring = m g.
The spring force is related to the displacement x of the spring from its equilibrium position by Hooke's Law: F_spring = k x.
Substituting F_spring = m g into Hooke's Law gives k x = m g, solving for x gives x = m g / k.

When the upward force F is applied to block A, the forces acting on A are the applied force F (upward), the gravitational force F_gravity = m g (downward), and the spring force F_spring = k x (downward).
The net force F_net acting on A is F_net = F - m g - k x.
Substitute x = m g / k into the equation F_net = F - m g - k x to get F_net = F - m g - m g, simplifying to F_net = F - 2 m g.
Using Newton's second law, the initial acceleration a of block A is given by a = F_net / m.
Substitute F_net = F - 2 m g into a = F_net / m to get a = (F - 2 m g) / m, simplifying to a = F / m - 2 g.
The magnitude of the initial acceleration of block A is a = F / m - 2 g.
